newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgaria lev eases on peg-linked c.bank fx buying.
newsitem.headline: Bulgaria lev eases on peg-linked c.bank fx buying.

text.p: The lev closed at 972-977 per mark, down from the opening's 969-973 after the central bank started bidding for foreign currency to prevent further lev gains ahead of a currency board peg, dealers said.

"The central bank began bidding for foreign currency in the afternoon when most final clients, which offered marks and dollars for levs to meet pending payments have already left the market," a commercial bank dealers said.
Central bank officials were unavailable for comment.

Traders said the central bank was trying to absorb higher foreign currency supply from clients and preserve market stability, averting a lev rise prior to a 1,000 levs-per-mark peg under a currency board system from July 1.
The lev closed at 1,673-1,680 per dollar, softer from the morning's 1,670-1,673 and in line with the mark/dollar cross on international markets.
Dealers said the central bank will probably continue buying foreign currency in the week to July 1 to sustain a lev fall so that the market could gradually adjust to the peg rate.
"The central bank will try to bridge the current gap between the market lev/mark rate and the peg rate by July 1 to ensure stability," another bank dealer said.
From next month the lev will trade at a fixed exchange rate of 1,000 to the mark, the anchor in an IMF-prescribed currency board system aimed to stabilise the economy.
